description: From Middle English situacioun, situacion, from Middle French situation, from Medieval Latin situatio (“position, situation”), from situare (“to locate, place”), from Latin situs (“a site”). Equivalent to situate +‎ -ion.

entries.meaning: The combination of circumstances at a given moment; a state of affairs.
examples: The United States is in an awkward situation with debt default looming.

entries.meaning: The way in which something is positioned vis-à-vis its surroundings.
examples: The Botanical Gardens are in a delightful situation on the river bank.

entries.meaning: The place in which something is situated; a location.
examples: [Hibíscus] speciòsus is the most splendid, and deserves a situation in every garden.

entries.meaning: Position or status with regard to conditions and circumstances.
(UK) A position of employment; a post.
examples: You take a morning paper from the top of the stack
And read the situations from the front to the back
The only job that's open need a man with a knack
So put it right back in the rack Jack.

entries.meaning: A difficult or unpleasant set of circumstances; a problem.
examples: Boss, we've got a situation here…

entries.meaning: (US, film industry) An individual movie theater.
examples: This survey includes all key situations (including Paramount Gulf Theaters) as well as suburban runs and small-town situations.
She is working some sort of amazing burgundy chiffon situation with gold piping.
